ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about censorship and different aspects of Chinese media.

Knowledge of contemporary Chinese government structures  especially those related to media industries. I also learned a lot about different fields of art in China such as contemporary art, modern film movements, and science fiction novels.
Different angles of looking at China, more from the folk level other than state level (like arts).
surveys of contemporary Chinese media (film, news TV, art), Western perceptions of China, history of economic, social and political formations of Chinese media
I learned about western views of China and also about how Chinese media shapes domestic narratives.
The course introduced me to new topics related to Chinese media

I learned more about the Chinese governmental systems of censorship, relevant history of PRC, and various pieces of pop and official media cultures to help inform us of how these entities have been affected by various regimes of censorship and control. We learned new ways to analyze media.
Deeper understanding of Chinese society, popular culture and politics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: moderately light workload, very interesting topics, Dr. Cao guides discussion well and provides lots of context ======== Weaknesses: group presentations could have been more organized, a few readings were very field-specific
A few of the readings were very hard to wrap my head around, but some of the concepts are just that complex so I think it is okay.

The strengths are that the topics are super interesting and approachable. The weaknesses are that the course didn't seem to have a clear topic. The title of the class refers to media, and our units were structured around a different form of media (art, movies, novels, etc.), but we didn't analyze them as media in the context of their uses in China. Rather, we only looked at Chinese versions of these media. Other than this, I think the course was a lot of fun, especially because my classmates had a lot of interesting opinions and perspectives.
Strength: systematic studies of the Chinese media from comprehensive perspectives.
It was very interesting and teaches a lot about China, its relationship with the West, and specific examples of film, literature, art, and history.

Strengths: interesting readings, lots of opportunities for students to engage with the material during class, knowledgable professor. Weaknesses: sometimes the readings felt random, and there wasn't a clear progression or theme throughout the course. Touched on lots of different subjects and ideas, but it would have been nice to have more of a focus.
The course material had great variety. Some of the readings were not as interesting.

I enjoyed the learning in our course, the writing assignments, and the feedback we received from the writing assignment. The only part of the course that I didn't think was necessary was perhaps the midterm report project; I didn't end up connecting this project to my final.
Very engaging and fun discussions and projects

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Many great readings, films, and insights. Workload is not bad either.
Yes, great class and it was actually fun for several of the sessions since we looked at authentic Chinese media, such as movies.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in studying modern China. A lot of the courses on China at Yale are about politics, or about ancient history/poetry. It's nice to take a class about Chinese culture that isn't about ancient history or about political turmoil. Some of the materials that we work with  especially the films  are excellent as well.
Yes. A great course to learn about China. It was the most objective course about China.
Yes, it is very interesting and an accessible seminar on modern China.
Yes! If interested in learning more about Chinese media.
Yes. It is a great class and the professor was great

Definitely would suggest this course to anyone interested in the topics of media, China, and US-China relations. This course was super interesting and if you have interest in the topics there is no reason why you wouldn't enjoy the class.
Yes, if you are interested in Chinese society and culture
